thread.title: Uber Freight Rolls Out incentives to Lure Scarce Truck Drivers

author: Erica E. Phillips
title: Uber Freight Rolls Out incentives to Lure Scarce Truck Drivers
text:
1 COMMENTS Uber Technologies Inc. is facing a problem trying to break into the freight market that’s rarely an issue in its ride-hailing expansion: a shortage of drivers.
The San Francisco-based business has built a world-wide empire using its app to connect people that need a ride to automobiles and drivers, effectively adding new capacity to a taxi marketplace that hadn’t changed for decades. The Uber Freight app seeks users and trucks that are already hauling freight, however, and most of those are in high demand in a U.S. shipping market that’s weighed down by a lack of drivers to handle big rigs.
Analysts say Uber Freight needs scale in its services to attract business and compete in a market crowded with freight brokers—companies that match industrial shipments to trucks and drivers looking for freight loads. But it needs more truck drivers on its app in order to gain that scale.
“It’s all about getting capacity,” said Evan Armstrong, president of logistics-consulting firm Armstrong & Associates. “You never want to have to turn down a load to a customer because you can’t find a truck.”
‘ You never want to have to turn down a load to a customer because you can’t find a truck. ’
—Evan Armstrong, Armstrong & Associates. In an effort to attract drivers, Uber Freight this week launched an incentive program offering discounts on fuel, tires, maintenance and the purchase of new and used vehicles. Drivers who use the Uber Freight app to book a load at least once a month are eligible for the discounts under agreements Uber struck with various service providers.
Uber Freight also touts its ability to pay drivers quickly—”within a few days,” according to Eric Berdinis, product manager for the app.
Mr. Armstrong said the speed with which Uber can pay its drivers can be a key factor in a competitive market. “That’s one thing they have to do, a quick-pay operation where they pay drivers in a fast fashion, especially with carrier capacity being so tight,” he said.
Discount incentives like Uber Freight’s new “Plus” program are already offered by other brokers or through membership in the Owner Operator Independent Drivers Association, analysts said.
A general shortage of truck capacity in the U.S. was exacerbated late last year when a federal rule went into effect requiring drivers’ hours on the road be tracked electronically through devices installed in their cabs. At the same time, strong consumer and industrial activity has kept freight networks busy, leading to capacity constraints and higher shipping costs as truckers raised freight rates.

The business includes a handful of operators that handle billions of dollars of business annually, including C.H. Robinson Worldwide Inc., XPO Logistics Inc. and Echo Global Logistics Inc. But a large share of shipments is handled by hundreds of small freight brokers that may have only a handful of employees.
The larger operators are investing heavily in technology, including apps for smartphones that function like Uber’s app. Greenwich, Conn.-based XPO this week said it had extended capabilities for its load-matching app to Europe.
Uber Freight launched in Texas about a year ago and has expanded to all 48 of the lower U.S. states. The company says 70% to 80% of its freight is on routes under 500 miles.
“Just as Uber was able to provide opportunities for drivers to go out on their own and be in control of their earnings, we see the same kind of trend happening in the freight industry,” Mr. Berdinis said.
